content.statement: Monads must satisfy three laws: left identity (return a >>= f ≡ f a), right identity (m >>= return ≡ m), and associativity ((m >>= f) >>= g ≡ m >>= (\x -> f x >>= g)).

explanation.intuition: Monad laws ensure composition behaves sensibly. Left identity: wrapping then unwrapping does nothing. Right identity: unwrapping then wrapping does nothing. Associativity: chaining operations can be regrouped without changing meaning.
explanation.key_insight: These laws guarantee monadic composition is coherent and predictable. They enable equational reasoning: you can refactor monadic code by applying laws, confident the behavior won't change.
explanation.technical_details: The laws can be stated using either bind (>>=) or join (μ) and return (η). With bind: three identity and associativity laws. With join: μ∘Mμ = μ∘μM and μ∘Mη = μ∘ηM = id. Both formulations are equivalent.

left_identity.description: Returning a value then binding is the same as just applying the function
left_identity.intuition: Wrapping then immediately unwrapping is a no-op

right_identity.intuition: Unwrapping then rewrapping is a no-op

associativity.latex: (m >>= f) >>= g \equiv m >>= (\lambda x. f(x) >>= g)
associativity.description: Order of nesting bind operations doesn't matter
associativity.intuition: Chaining computations can be regrouped like function composition

associativity.description: Flattening M(M(M(a))) works the same regardless of which layer we flatten first
associativity.diagram: M(M(M(a))) can flatten outer or inner layers first, result is same

left_identity.intuition: M(η(a)) → M(a) via join is identity

right_identity.description: Wrapping at outer level then flattening is identity
right_identity.intuition: η(M(a)) → M(a) via join is identity

verification_example.associativity: (Just 5 >>= half) >>= toString ≡ Just 5 >>= (\x -> half x >>= toString)

sources.citation: Mac Lane, S. (1971). Categories for the Working Mathematician. Springer.
